evidence.text: enforce Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e, et seq.

extracted.value: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

evidence.text: Plaintiff, the United States of America (“United States”),

extracted.value: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as United States of America

evidence.text:
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS
A.  DFD’s Entry‑Level Firefighter Selection Process

8.  The United States, through the United States Department of Justice, conducted an investigation of the policies and practices of Defendant with respect to its screening and selection of applicants for the entry‑level firefighter position at DFD and the discriminatory effect of such practices on African‑American applicants. The Department of Justice notified Defendant of that investigation and of the United States’ determination.

9.  Durham oversees all municipal agencies within the city, including DFD.  Through DFD, Durham employs firefighters who, among other things, are responsible for providing

…
The Complaint alleges that the City’s Durham Fire Department (DFD) employs a multi‑step selection process for entry‑level firefighters that includes a written examination (the Comprehensive Examination Battery, or CEB) and that this process has a disproportionate adverse impact on African‑American applicants, violating Title VII § 703(a)(2) and 42 U.S.C. § 2000e‑2(k). The Complaint documents that DFD’s use of the CEB is not job‑related or consistent with business necessity, and that African‑American applicants are less likely to pass the exam and to receive interview offers compared to white applicants.

extracted.value: The Complaint alleges that the City’s Durham Fire Department (DFD) employs a multi‑step selection process for entry‑level firefighters that includes a written examination (the Comprehensive Examination Battery, or CEB) and that this process has a disproportionate adverse impact on African‑American applicants, violating Title VII § 703(a)(2) and 42 U.S.C. § 2000e‑2(k). The Complaint documents that DFD’s use of the CEB is not job‑related or consistent with business necessity, and that African‑American applicants are less likely to pass the exam and to receive interview offers compared to white applicants.

evidence.text: a. refrain from using written tests to screen and select applicants for DFD entry-level firefighter positions where such uses result in a disparate impact on African Americans, are not job related for the position in question and consistent with business necessity, and/or do not otherwise meet the requirements of Section 703(k) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(k);

extracted.value: Plaintiff: refrain from using written tests to screen and select applicants for DFD entry-level firefighter positions where such uses result in a disparate impact on African Americans, are not job related for the position in question and consistent with business necessity, and/or do not otherwise meet the requirements of Section 703(k) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(k)

evidence.text: b. provide make whole remedial relief to all persons who have suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in this Complaint;

extracted.value: Plaintiff: provide make whole remedial relief to all persons who have suffered individual loss as a result of the discrimination alleged in this Complaint

evidence.text: c. adopt other appropriate nondiscriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies and practices

extracted.value: Plaintiff: adopt other appropriate nondiscriminatory measures to correct the present effects of its discriminatory policies and practices

evidence.text: This Court has jurisdiction of this action under 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-6(b) and 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1343(a)(3) and 1345.
KRISTEN CLARKE       SANDRA J. HAIRSTON  Assistant Attorney General  United States Attorney  Civil Rights Division  Middle District of North Carolina
